Recommended reading is my way to offer others a short cut, somewhere to *start* learning for themselves. I couldn't find anyone who could tell me where to begin. So this is my attempt to remedy that for others, the results of trial and error over 24 yrs. I hope you find it useful

I had to learn the answers for myself the hard way, mostly chasing up obscure footnotes. I've read some great books and articles and some less useful ones over the years. I've got lost down a host of rabbit holes. It wasn't a very efficient way to learn - though it was often fun

What on earth is contango? What is option volatility? How does a national grid work? Why is there a bitter rivalry between Saudi Arabia and Iran? How easy is to block the Strait of Hormuz? And a host of other questions. But it was hard to find a book that could answer them

When I started to work on oil and energy, I knew nothing about the subject at all. I would ask people how I could find out more. And the only thing they could recommend was reading The Prize by Daniel Yergin. It's a very fine history book but it didn't answer all my questions.

I started writing about oil and energy in 1996 as a very small part of my first job at Oxford Analytica. Oil became a more important part of my role at Sempra Commodities. Then a full time focus when I joined Reuters in 2008.

Recommended reading started out in Sep 2014 in response to requests for references from colleagues and as an aide memoire. I have a terrible memory so it contains details of books and articles I might want to refer to again. From the start I also hoped it would also fill a gap
@Bonnie_Chuck Reader Bullard is very amusing. Start with Two Kings in Arabia

@jsdstanfield EVERYONE starts with The Prize, and often ends with it; I want to encourage people to read more widely around the amazing literature. Plus I've never finished The Prize. I've bought three copies over the years and just not got around to it. I promise to read The Prize eventually!

Poor weather in Sep-Mar reduces effective social distance (people crowd together more indoors). But coronavirus and associated mandatory and self-imposed curbs on social mixing increase effective social distance. Weather conditions themselves are variable. Net effect is ambiguous

In 2020/21, increased social distancing (mandated and voluntary) is likely to reduce transmission of other respiratory diseases, which should lower death rate. But increased transmission of coronavirus, which is more lethal, will tend to increase death rate. Net effect is complex

From mid Sep, the increase in social mixing, deterioration in the weather, and movement of more activity indoors, would normally increase the incidence of respiratory diseases and the associated death rate. This year the normal colds and influenza are joined by coronavirus risk

Late Aug and early Sep is usually the low-point in the annual mortality cycle. Deaths linked to respiratory infections decline in the summer with more activity outside and schools on an extended holiday. From mid-Sep, the death rate will start to rise towards a peak in mid-Jan

MEGACITIES, suburbs, secondary cities and provinces are always part of a complex web of social, economic and political relations, an integrated system, that is in constant change
RELATIONSHIPS between primary cities, secondary cities and small towns/rural are constantly being redefined by technology and costs and this is another one of those redefinitions

OUTCOME is most likely to be a blend of more WFH, more working from secondary cities, and some continued working from central metro offices. Technology has shifted the trade off between those modes of working and the epidemic has shattered some inertia and accelerated change

@ErnestScheyder NEW HIRE acclimatisation, socialisation and cultural transmission are probably the biggest issue raised by massive WFH. But set against those challenges is enormous time/energy/financial cost of twice daily mass people movement and high costs of central metro office space

@neb967 Depends whether organisations measure inputs (office time etc) or outputs (production, revenue contribution etc). Most organisations are still input focused (it‚Äôs easier). But trend is towards output measurement and I expect that to speed up

@neb967 There will be some jobs that are still more effectively performed from a central office in a major metro area. But others will shift to secondary cities or WFH where costs are lower and productivity the same

BIG SOCIAL and economic shocks like coronavirus tend to accelerate change along pre-existing trends of which WFH was one and the rising importance of secondary cities was perhaps another. But the scale if not direction of the permanent shift is still uncertain

BIG PROBLEMS arise from the scale and speed of any change towards WFH. Huge amounts of capital and labour are invested in central cities like London. Shifting that away from the centre would involve enormous upheaval. Critical question is inertia versus forces compelling change

FWIW I am hoping never to return to the daily commute. I have access to all the information I need at home. I‚Äôm more productive. And I save 1.0-1.5 hours of dead travel time every day on overcrowded uncomfortable and virus transmitting trains. Winning all round

LONGER working from home lasts, the more it will morph from temporary expedient into a more durable structural shift. If an organisation can cope with WFH for 9 months it can probably cope for 3 years. The length of epidemic as well as its severity is driving structural change

There is a fascinating story to be told about how a bureaucratic control document became a symbol of national pride and prestige, invested with quasi-mythical status, a nexus, perhaps the most important one, between citizen/subject and the state
Internal passport-like systems still exist by the way, most notably China's hukou system

If it hasn't been written already, someone should write a history of passports, their role in security, societal control, identity verification, and forging national identities. I would definitely read it with great interest

I used to view my passport as a symbol of freedom; now I increasingly see it as a symbol of unfreedom. They are part of the complex machinery of the modern state, part of the complicated trade off between movement and security, citizen and non-citizen, free and unfree

Passport requirements were scrapped for a time in much of Europe in the second half of the nineteenth century, and the abolition was seen as an affirmation of freedom. But they were reintroduced with the advent of the First World War, as part of a wider set of security controls

In history, passports were required by diplomats, state-licensed foreign traders, but also by serfs and peasants who wanted to move outside their own community around the rest of their country. Passport systems in Russia were an integral part of the policing state.

The passport's wording promises freedom of movement, but is actually part of an elaborate system of control, so I can go only where it is permitted. I cannot leave the country without one. I cannot enter another country without one. It determines what jobs I can and cannot have

But more recently, I began to wonder about the purpose of the passport. Consular services for passport holders are very limited. If I get into trouble abroad, Her Britannic Majesty won't send the navy to break me out of prison, or even impose sanctions.

For many decades I was very proud of my passport with its stirring imperial rhetoric: it seemed to promise worldwide protection by Her Britannic Majesty's government from foreign governments who might seek to do me harm or block my freedom of movement.

My British passport opens with the rousing words: "Her Britannic Majesty's Secretary of State requests and requires in the Name of Her Majesty all those whom it may concern to allow the bearer to pass freely without let or hindrance" etc

PASSPORTS have become a symbol of national pride but were originally introduced to control movement of citizens as much as foreigners. The need for a passport represents a loss of freedom, the idea people should not be allowed to move unless the authorities expressly permit it https://t.co/4JHeAGA987

@ErnestScheyder Every embassy and consulate also acts as a spy base, with intelligence officers given official cover as diplomats. The critical question is whether Houston consulate was engaged in more egregious espionage than normal, leading to closure, or if this is part of a broader crackdown
Both sides need to weigh short-term responses and need to look tough against longer-term strategy. It‚Äôs not clear what that strategy is yet
Of course I‚Äôm not privy to the discussions in Zhongnanhai, but this must be an option under discussion, and there is a certain logic from Beijing‚Äôs perspective

Restricting or downgrading the US/U.K. diplomatic presence in the city would be consistent with the strategy of political absorption, implying foreign missions should end up more like those in Shanghai, Wuhan, Chongqing etc, providing minimal consular services only

My working assumption has been for some time that China will absorb Hong Kong politically, turning it into something more like a provincial-city, while trying to preserve some economic and commercial dynamism, though recognising this may not be possible

I‚Äôm certain China‚Äôs top leaders will be reviewing the future U.S./U.K. presence in Hong Kong very closely after recent events and they will want to change it. The question is how far they decide to go at this point

* Response in kind to closure of Houston consulate

* China is clearly worried that US/U.K. using their consulates to encourage local opposition
CHINA closing the US/U.K. consulates would be an extremely strong responses and could be considered escalatory. But it has a certain internal logic:

@EnergzdEconomy AGREED

The concept of "compensatory cuts" has become very popular, but I still don't understand the mechanism that makes it effective. Appeals to self-interest? Appeals to OPEC solidarity? Soft loans? Threats to renew volume warfare? Threats to target specific customers? Something else?

I am puzzled why other members of OPEC+ would deepen their cuts to compensate for past underperformance while Russia and Saudi Arabia increase their own production. It seems irrational. Unless some form of threat/inducement has been made in the background. If so, what is it?

SAUDI ARABIA and RUSSIA are cutting their own production because it is in their own interest to do so, not as a charitable effort. If it remains in their own interest, they will maintain scheduled cuts, whether or not the laggards compensate for past under-compliance

COMPENSATORY CUTS concept seems implausible on face of it. If threat is "compensate or else we will raise production", there is no way to inflict pain on laggards without inflicting it on everyone. Saudi Arabia and Russia have no interest in restarting volume war at this point

QUESTION: what is the motivation for the OPEC+ laggards who did not fully comply with cuts in May/Jun to make compensating extra cuts in Aug/Sep? What threat/incentive/cajolery/inducement has been offered to them? Why would they cut more when others are starting to cut less?

Perhaps a more useful way of thinking about data is that it illustrates profoundly disruptive effect shale revolution (horizontal drilling + hydraulic fracturing) has had on oil since 2009. In any event. I hope you find it useful, even if you disagree with  conclusion

Here is my contribution, offered with humility and an acknowledgement it is likely to be wrong. In a few years, we'll discover whether it contained any useful insight, or was just another addition to the pile of old, inaccurate forecasts littering the oil market in recent decades

But can we say something useful in broad terms about likely level of prices over course of the next cycle or next few cycles, based on what we can observe about how production, consumption and prices have behaved over last ten years, an empirical rather than theoretical approach?

Those of you who know me well, know I am very sceptical about whether it is possible or useful to forecast oil prices. We know prices are cyclical but the timing and magnitude of those price swings has eluded even the most ambitious forecasters and modellers

BRITAIN's political temperature is set to rise rapidly over the summer as the full cost of the epidemic and lockdown become apparent in terms of lost businesses and employment

BUSINESS and government are already trying to shift blame for coming redundancy wave; why businesses such as British Airways have warned about job losses; hospitality sector is pushing for dilution of distancing rules; and government keeps talking positively about re-opening

REDUNDANCY and advance notification requirements will ensure the wave of job losses will start well before Aug, likely in the second half of Jun, accelerating through Jul. The resulting contraction in employment will then likely trigger a normal business-cycle downturn

FROM AUGUST however keeping workers on payroll will start to incur a small but significant cost. Employers will have to estimate their real need for labour post-lockdown. No employer will want to lose cash on payroll if avoidable

JOB SUBSIDIES have given employers a free option to wait and see what the post-lockdown world will look like. And most employers are fundamentally decent: given a chance to keep people on payroll at zero cost they have done so

MOST of these sectors are not financially viable at pre-epidemic scale of output and employment under social distancing. So far the resulting unemployment has been hidden by government job subsidies but as these are withdrawn from Aug the scale of joblessness will become apparent

BRITAIN faces a huge wave of redundancies in the next few weeks as lockdown gives way to a structural and cyclical recession - with aviation, accommodation, tourism, leisure, entertainment, food and drink services, high street retail and business services most at risk

WONDERLAND is purely imaginary, but its economic trajectory bears some resemblance to the United States, as shown in these forecasts from the U.S. Congressional Budget Office: https://t.co/SxGAAUsu1S

WONDERLAND's government and its central bank achieve a remarkable post-crisis stabilisation and re-opening, but it is still not enough to achieve the fabled V-shaped recovery, and there are long-term losses of output, income and employment that Wonderland cannot make disappear

WONDERLAND's economy ends up permanently smaller ("scarred") despite a relatively rapid bounce in the aftermath of the negative shock. The shock has lingering consequences for Wonderland's inhabitants even though the government was fairly successful supporting a vigorous recovery

WONDERLAND's people feel poorer, however, despite the extraordinarily rapid recovery. 

By end-2020, Wonderland's economy is -5% smaller than if it had continued growing on its previous trend

By the end of 2021, the economy is still -2.8% smaller than on it's previous trajectory https://t.co/6RbC07iJzZ
WONDERLAND's enhanced growth rate lasts until March 2022, spurred by supportive fiscal and monetary policies, before reverting to its long-term trend of +2.4% per year

From Sep 2020 onwards, with output nearing the pre-crisis level, Wonderland's recovery slows. But the economy is still growing at an annual rate of +5%, roughly double the pre-crisis growth rate of +2.4%.
WONDERLAND's economy has recovered to around -5% below its pre-crisis output by the end of Aug, following all this strong growth

WONDERLAND is fortunate; the worst of the shock passes relatively quickly. Output rises by +5% in May, then another +7% in Jun, as businesses resume operations. The recovery really accelerates with +10% growth month-on-month in both Jul and Aug.
WONDERLAND is pottering along close to its trend growth rate at the start of 2020. But then the economy is hit by a terrible shock causing its output to plunge by -30% in April

WONDERLAND is a prosperous advanced economy that has been growing at an average rate of around +2.4% per year for the last five years, very similar to its long-run trend rates over the last 10 years (+2.3%) and 20 years (+2.1%)
WONDERLAND is an imaginary economy that allows us to conduct a thought experiment about how it recovers after a once-in-a-century negative shock: https://t.co/wEmmUZPq2l

Don‚Äôt get me wrong: I hope there *is* a safe effective vaccine found quickly and deployed rapidly. I‚Äôm amazed at the ingenuity of the scientists working hard to develop one. But I‚Äôm a realist too and I want policymakers to pursue realist strategies

Policymakers have to consider a reasonable worst case scenario in which there is no vaccine, or it‚Äôs only partially effective, or doesn‚Äôt confer lasting immunity, or takes several years to develop and deploy widely. 

Policy has to be developed with this non-zero risk in mind

In reality, probability of developing a safe effective vaccine in the next year is greater than zero but less than 100%. 

‚ÄúUntil there is a vaccine‚Äù implicitly assumes probability is 100% over some reasonable time horizon  
 
That cannot be foundation for a sensible policy

‚ÄúUntil there is a vaccine ...‚Äù that tricky phrase and assumption again.

@Brentwoodbird Totally agree ... it‚Äôs the worst sort of elitist behaviour from people who like to preach that ‚Äúwe‚Äôre all in this together‚Äù

I feel strongly because there are parts of the Ferguson-Cummings lockdown strategy I think are seriously flawed both in conception and execution, AND YET I‚Äôve still respected lockdown as the collective choice of the community, however wrongheaded I think some of it is

It‚Äôs hard to see why 14,000 fines have been issued, mostly to young people with no power and status, while Ferguson and Cummings are protected and apparently done nothing worse than shown lack of judgment
If the rules are not suitable for Ferguson and Cummings, they aren‚Äôt suitable for everyone else. And if the rules apply to everyone, they must apply to those in power and helping design them

If Ferguson thinks it‚Äôs ok to see other people once you‚Äôve had the virus and got antibodies, then we should all be allowed the same privilege. And if it‚Äôs ok for Cummings to drive around the country visiting people, we should all be able to

If anything, the rules apply with extra force to Ferguson and Cummings. Unlike the rest of us, who have had no input into them, but are expected nonetheless to follow them, Ferguson and Cummings were on the inside, helping to shape them.

But if I do decide to rely on my own judgment and get caught I will have to accept the consequences and won‚Äôt receive much sympathy from Ferguson and Cummings. That‚Äôs what living in a country governed by law means. The rules apply equally to everyone

If the lockdown continues too long and the quality of the decision-making doesn‚Äôt improve significantly, *I* may start to exercise my own judgment too about which rules to follow and which to ignore.

Encouraged by government, police have been fining people for lockdown breaches and Home Sec. wants to impose fines for breaking quarantine. The rest of us have to follow the rules whether we agree or not. But somehow it‚Äôs ok for Ferguson and Cummings to follow their own judgment
If everyone decided the rules did not apply to them, or could be specially interpreted, like Ferguson and Cummings, there would be chaos and the lockdown strategy they both advocated would collapse.

There are lots of aspects of the lockdown strategy I disagree with. The quality of both the scientific advice and political decision-making is poor. I would have done things differently. But so far I have observed the rules while reserving my right to say I disagree

Neil Ferguson and Dominic Cummings both deserve censure for same reason: they helped design the lockdown strategy, then decided the rules applied to everyone else but not to them. Both are open to the charge of hypocrisy and elitism (one rule for us another for ordinary people)

Economies cannot recover until all those frivolous non-essential retailers and services restart. Policymakers and journalists need to focus a bit more on the consumer side. Industrial production is good. But retail sales and personal consumption expenditures matter just as much

But the production side of the economy will not restart sustainably until the consumption side recovers as well. There is no point making cars, washing machines and new homes unless they can be sold to consumers or other businesses.

Policymakers and journalists tend to focus on production because it is more "serious" and "essential", while consumption is often characterised as "frivolous" and non-essential. Puritans like hard work, lots of saving, and deferred pleasure (if pleasure at all)
But unless the consumption side of the economy starts to pick up, the production side will stall because there is no point producing if you can't sell, something China is starting to discover

Policymakers are focused on getting manufacturing, construction, business services and supply chains re-opened and working so the economy can start making money again. Re-opening retailers, services firms, leisure and entertainment industries have much less priority

In the real world, production and consumption are interdepedent. But as policymakers try to chart a way out of the coronavirus-induced lockdowns, a supply-side focus is taking root, to the exclusion of demand-side issues

POLITICAL ECONOMISTS have been divided for centuries over which is more important: production (productivity-focused supply-side puritans) or consumption (consumer-focused demand-side hedonists). Does supply bring forth its own demand, or does demand drive supply?

@smccarthy55 I suspect some Australians, New Zealanders, South Africans and others may be slightly surprised too at their omission - which shows the dangers of playing politics with history

@E1_London It's not about creating a moral balance sheet for the 20th century, which is far beyond the scope of Twitter, but about remembering the war as it really was, with all its messy complexity, not as it has been re-imagined in the light of Cold War and post-Cold War rivalries
@PatrickHeren Clark versus Bronowsk is a common debate - but my money is still on Bronowski
@Hedgewatch1 TRUE, but I found "Civilisation" less compelling than either "The Ascent of Man" or "The World at War" and it has not stood the test of time as well

@ctype_real Totally. Let's remember all the millions who perished during the war, from fighting, bombing, starvation, purges and death camps. The most fitting way to commemorate their suffering and sacrifices is to remember the truth, in all its messy complexity

@ctype_real YES. This is not the place for a full moral balance sheet of C20th history. But I am sure you agree we can acknowledge the sacrifices made by millions of people in the Soviet Union as part of the United Nations effort to defeat Nazism rather than airbrush them out of history

"The World at War" is one of the two greatest pieces of television ever made (the other was Jacob Bronowski's "The Ascent of Man"). Television can often be a shallow, inaccurate medium but those two series illustrated how it can also take a serious look at the past and the world

Perhaps the most remarkable thing about the series, apart from its absolutely extraordinary archival footage, was its attempt to examine the war from all sides, a remarkable feat of historical objectivity given that the events recorded were less than 30 years old at that point

"The World at War", a 26-part documentary first broadcast in 1973/74, commissioned by Thames Television about WWII, using archival footage from all sides, remains one of the most spectacular, honest and thoughtful pieces of television ever produced: https://t.co/HXLAjXqY1d

@JReade_WGC This isn't the place to do a full accounting of who paid what in terms of materiel and lives. But I think it's important to acknowledge the tremendous sacrifices of all sides. Like it or not, the Soviet Union was *at the time* our ally in the United Nations to defeat Nazism

History is complicated. The Red Army can be BOTH a liberator of Europe from Nazism and a post-war oppressor of the countries of Eastern Europe. But we have to embrace history for all that complexity and ambiguity, otherwise it's not history but an alternative reality

You don't have to be an apologist for Stalin or communism to think this is an insult to the people of former Soviet Union who died in their millions to help defeat Nazism. I am constantly amazed how little the horrors of the eastern front are remembered in Washington and London: https://t.co/kFURRTOhWl

I learned more about finance, business and economy from sitting on a trading floor for seven years than from any university course or textbook. It was best education ever. I got to learn an amazing amount from our traders but also from our treasurers, compliance and legal staff

In 2001 at Enron and again in 2007/8, I got a ring-side view of just how quickly credit can be cut at first hint of counterparty risk. Liquidation-only is fast and brutal. Normally, it is reserved for individual counterparties but can be imposed when entire contract becomes risky

In my former role as in-house analyst, I remember sending an internal email that Fed officials were expected to visit Bear Stearns at weekend. In minutes, our treasurer had sent an all-firm email instructing all further trades with Bear were to be risk-reducing (liquidation-only)

LIQUIDATION-ONLY rule is usually employed to control counterparty risk, e.g. when a client's ability to pay is in question or whole financial system is under strain, but they can be introduced when it's no longer clear a contract can settle normally because of abnormal conditions

CME/NYMEX Jun WTI contract is basically now dead since the physical settlement process is no longer guaranteed to work. More brokers are likely to introduce liquidation-only rule to limit exposure and risk of violent price swings as Jun contract heads towards expiry

FUTURES-ONLY traders should never ever get trapped at the front of the curve unless they want to get killed by physical traders. Incidentally, same is true for all commodities (e.g. LME spreads within the third-Weds prime date and TOM-NEXT trades)

FUTURES-ONLY traders must avoid expiry at all costs, and should move positions well before the contract's expiry date. Only play in the cash market if you have the ability to make/take physical delivery (means ownership of physical commodity, logistics and storage capability)

TRADING RULE #1. If you are a futures trader, with no ability to make or take physical delivery, never, ever allow your futures position to get anywhere near to expiry where it will become a cash position by default.

In WTI, the problem is compounded because contract is settled by physical delivery at Cushing, where storage space now very tight. But congestion is showing up even in Brent, which isn't physically settled, at least on the futures side. Lack of storage is depressing nearby prices

For some time, it's been clear the cash market is very congested in both Brent and WTI, with pressure on storage. Discounts for cash crude have been even wider than for futures contracts. So as front-month Brent (or WTI) contract expires and goes to cash, discount becomes extreme

In most market states, the contango/backwardation is steepest for nearby weeks and months, and shallower for dates further out. Same is true for the cash market. So when a futures contract expires and trading moves to the cash market, there is often an accelerated shift in prices

FUTURES AND CASH MARKETS

@KevinCalabria1 You can make a case for cancelling or allowing sporting events. There is good science on this. But the key point is to have a comprehensive integrated strategy and articulate it

@KevinCalabria1 Most research has shown relatively low risk from open air events. The U.K. pandemic plan envisaged letting them continue to maintain sense of normality and morale. Shutdowns mostly for symbolic reasons. COVID spreads through close personal contact and high-touch surfaces

@KevinCalabria1 Other policies and choices are possible but there needs to be a clearly defined and articulated strategy. Operating without a strategy is like setting off on a voyage without map or navigation equipment

@KevinCalabria1 My recommendation: 
* Isolate old and vulnerable 
* Return to near-normal for rest of population but with as much social-distancing as possible and big increase in hand/respiratory hygiene
* Controlled epidemic through least vulnerable part of population to build herd immunity

@KevinCalabria1 I‚Äôm not sure how we got onto the subject of Trump. I was writing about the U.K. though it has broader international applicability. I can give you a strategy if you like. But the point is I‚Äôm not the decision-maker. I can and should however hold those decision-makers to account

@KevinCalabria1 No one said it would be easy, but a government without a clear strategy is just improvising and more likely to make mistakes. Strategies can and do change change as circumstances alter. But a government without a strategy is rudderless

SO cut the lectures and threats minister and start showing some respect for the big efforts almost everyone is making. Positive encouragement rather than threats more likely to sustain the effort needed

@AlasdairEcon Partly it‚Äôs the triumph of hope over experience. Governments WANTED to believe the problem could be, had been, successfully contained, because the alternative was too painful to confront.

Most epidemics start much earlier and spread faster, undetected, than originally believed. COVID-19 has accelerated so terribly in part because governments wrongly thought they were successfully containing it and so failed to prepare for widespread transmission

When history of the pandemic is written (and re-written many times) one of main conclusions likely to be the virus spread much further and faster than realised and acknowledged at time. While many countries were still focused on ‚Äúcontainment‚Äù the epidemic was accelerating rapidly

@woolfiex50 "Many centuries later, Europeans began to call it the Black Death ... The reason for this is probably a misunderstanding, a mistranslation of the Latin expression *atra mors*, in which atra may mean both terrible and black. It has nothing to do with diagnostic symptoms"
@woolfiex50 From memory several centuries later; my main source book is in the office and unavailable. At time the time it was often called the pestilence
@pauladkins @DouglasPollitt Far from it. We can treat plague very effectively today with antibiotics so it should rarely be fatal. But for contemporaries it must have been terrifying
@DouglasPollitt And the case fatality rate for Black Death was 80% which must have made it terrifying

Black Death was arguably the biggest calamity for mankind in thousands of years, but always important to remember, everything we think we know is based on estimates and reconstructions from some very fragmentary records and some very sparse references in contemporary chronicles.

Beyond clergy appointments, will registrations and some local death-fee records, we have very little data on either population before Black Death or number/percentage who died, though social historians and demographers have made some impressive estimates with what little we have

Clergy visited the sick and dying to administer last rites, but usually very briefly, and wore heavy full length robes that gave some protection from plague-causing flea bites. They also tended to live in stone rather than wooden houses with fewer resident rats

Much of what we know about Black Death in England is based on clergy (clerics were important so good records were kept). We then have to extrapolate from clergy to rest of society in terms of spread and fatality, making assumptions/adjustments for attack rates and susceptibility

For many parts of England, we also have good data on the appointment of each new parish priest by the local bishop (and implicitly the death of the old priest 2-4 months earlier). So we can track the spread of plague and death rate among the clergy fairly accurately

Only the relatively wealthy tended to make wills, so it‚Äôs not representative of the whole of society, but they usually had to be registered with a court to be valid, so we can use registrations to track the spread of the C14th plague as it drew near and menaced communities

PANDEMICS make people think about their own mortality. One way we can track the spread of the Black Death in the 14th century, when statistics were almost totally absent, was the number of new wills written and registered https://t.co/1XwjqQKCKZ

STRATEGIC FAILURES are always hardest to correct because they come from the top of an organisation (in contrast to operational and tactical failures that can be blamed on lower officials and corrected more easily). OPEC+ strategy of cutting output to sustain prices isn't working

BLACK DEATH was transmitted over long distances along the major international trade routes of the 14th century, including the coastal shipping lanes and up the major rivers to inland cities, spreading from primary centres to secondary cities and then to smaller towns and villages https://t.co/kyAL6lBoaC

KEY PATHWAYS for the spread of Black Death included:
Theodosia in Crimea -> Constantinople
Theodosia -> Alexandria
Constantinople -> Sicily -> Italy -> Marseille
Bordeaux -> England -> Ireland, Norway and Germany
Ships were the disease-carrying aircraft of the 14th century

CORONAVIRUS has triggered a whole genre of stories about epidemics and globalisation. But international transmission along trade routes is not new. It was the key pathway for the spread of Black Death in the 14th century, not an era we tend to associated with globalisation: https://t.co/phucF8xg3K

So most of you will already have been exposed to the derivatives of the virus that killed an estimated 50 million people in 1918/19 and has killed millions more since then (‚Äú1918 influenza: the mother of all pendemics‚Äù, Taubenberger and Morens, 2006)

These viruses still circulate and are responsible for the seasonal influenza epidemics. The pandemic influenza of 1918/19 is the ‚Äúmother‚Äù of all subsequent influenza pandemics and epidemics.  It has been identified as the start of the current, third influenza pandemic cycle.

The pandemic influenza virus of 1918/19 (H1N1) has since mutated (a process known as ‚Äúantigenic drift‚Äù)  into modern variants of H1N1 and been reassorted with other viruses resulting the creation of H2N2 (‚ÄúAsian influenza‚Äù of 1956-58) and H3N2 (‚ÄúHong Kong influenza‚Äù of 1968-69).

PANDEMIC INFLUENZA in 1918/19 was unusual because it killed so many young adults around the age of 30, creating a W-shaped mortality curve, in contrast to a normal influenza outbreak, which kills mostly the very young and  old, leading to a characteristic U-shaped mortality curve https://t.co/gzXGxcgatt

In the meantime, my office orchids have to go home! Combined with the dozen or so I have at home already, I think I have run out of windowsills in the flat for them ... that's probably most urgent problem

Medium term plan is to move to a new house/apartment, set up a home office/library, and work from home at least 1 or 2 days per week. If lots of people do same, it would help achieve the 67% occupancy target

I wonder if I will end up working from home more, or ruthlessly come into the office early to ensure I get a desk? I'm a morning person so early starts no hardship (before joining Reuters I used to wake up at 0315 in Oxford for an 0630 start in London though I was younger then)

On practical side, I'll have to find a way to work without books; might not be too hard since most columns are written with online data, and I use the books mostly for background research, which doesn't have to happen in the office (looking up references might be tricky though)

On the commercial side, the cost savings should be significant: 33% reduction in the number of desks, and new desks will be somewhat smaller and more densely spaced, so total savings could be in the order of 50% per person

If people are not co-located with their team, or more people work outside the office, how will that impact on formal collaboration and less formal communications? Will agile desking break down silos and promote more cross-team working or not?

Plan envisages people continuing to sit with their current teams to maintain communication. I wonder how that will square with the need to average out occupancy rates (which is surely easier across a larger number than a smaller number of people - aka law of large numbers)?
Whatever happens, desk occupancy rates need to come down to 67%. I think that will most likely come about as a result of increased working from home, though we haven't discussed this yet
We've been repeatedly assured there will be enough desks for everyone who needs one based on occupancy studies over the last year. I'm a bit sceptical about that but we should find out soon

New system has desks for only 67% of current staff numbers so assumes on average staff will be in the office only two-thirds of the time. Most staff members currently have 5-6 weeks holiday per year, implying desk occupancy of around 89%. Some are part time, out interviewing etc

Great opportunity to see how transition from fixed desking to hot desking works in practice, how it changes working patterns, organisational culture etc. So I'm going to record my thoughts now, and then again in 1 month, 3 mths, 6 mths and 12mths, to create a contemporary record

(9) Coronavirus does raise multiple challenges for China's leaders, and for the question of political legitimacy, mostly via questions about economic competence, but they are  more complicated than Jamil's article allows, and the analogy with Chernobyl seems to me to be unlikely

(8) In the majority of cases, blame is pinned on specific errors and individuals rather than the system as a whole. Most systems have remarkable durability. Ruptures (such as the Tunisian spring) are less common than continuities (which therefore tend to be less remarked upon)

(7) Most political systems will blame specific actions by (usually) low-level officials for policy failures (it's how corporations, governments, and other organisations protect themselves from criticism). Plenty of recent examples in the world of politics, business and banking

(6) If there was a virus outbreak in London, New York or Sydney, how would the government's response be different and would it be more successful? Is epidemic control the right way to think about and measure political system legitimacy?

(5) There are plenty of reasons to criticise China's authoritarian top-down political system in general. There are also plenty of reasons to criticise response to the coronavirus outbreak in particular. But we should be careful about jumping from the specific to the general here

(4) Epidemics are NOT confined to authoritarian political systems and we need to be careful about ascribing problems of infection control to the nature of the government without evidence. China's aggressive quarantine system would probably not have been possible in OECD countries

(3) Nearly all political systems penalise low-level whistleblowers who try to tell truths which powerful system leaders find inconvenient. That characteristic is shared by both authoritarian and non-authoritarian systems, albeit to differing degrees

(2) Governments of all kinds tend to be slow to respond to a crisis such as an epidemic. For example, the slow U.S. response to Hurricane Katrina. That doesn't *necessarily* invalidate the political system's legitimacy.

There are a couple of problems with this piece, which is why I ultimately don't agree with Jamil:
(1) USSR was a failed system that failed to generate growth and rising living standards. Chernobyl became a symbol of a much larger failure. Not clear this analogy holds for China

Worth reading and thinking about carefully. I disagree with Jamil's conclusions and his analogy with Chernobyl. But it is worth thinking about whether the government's reaction to coronavirus will harm its political legitimacy or not https://t.co/oDch0b6G2v

BRITAIN's carriers and missile submarines have sucked money from rest of the budget, money that could have been more usefully spent on special forces, regular infantry, aircraft, and frigates/destroyers/patrol vessels, all of which would have added more to the country's security

BRITAIN's carriers don't even have a useful force projection role. The type of conflict the UK has fought in the last three decades has involved ground-launched aircraft and special forces/regular infantry that can  be more cheaply carried by other ships

BRITAIN's carriers have to be lucky every time and we only have one or two of them. A (hypersonic) missile or torpedo only has to get lucky once and potential adversaries will have hundreds or thousands of them

BRITAIN's vulnerable carriers need to be accompanied by expensive destroyers and submarines to protect them from attack, absorbing even more scarce resources. They are just big floating targets against sophisticated or even unsophisticated adversaries

BRITAIN's carriers are expensive white elephants that are extremely vulnerable to hypersonic missiles or torpedoes, or even ordinary ones. China, Russia and other countries are deploying thousands of such missile systems.

BRITAIN's missile submarines are designed to fight a type of sudden nuclear conflict with the USSR (a bolt from the blue attack without warning) that is no longer a major threat to the UK. It would be much cheaper to switch to air-launch, surface launch or ground-launch systems

BRITAIN's expensive aircraft carrier and missile submarine programmes have become a millstone around the defence budget and security strategy - absorbing huge amounts of funding but adding little in terms of useful capability: https://t.co/9fgp4SkyO0

WE CAN argue about whether high-speed rail or conventional rail lines would be best use of UK infrastructure budget. But the real scandal is the failure to build ANY new rail line capacity connecting the UK regions because the planning and decision-making system is so moribund

BRITAIN is still arguing about whether to build a high-speed rail link from London to the West Midlands and the North of England. In the meantime, China has built an entire nationwide high-speed network: https://t.co/Z29isENvit

@ZacharyLRogers AGREED. Nuclear weapons are probably not part of the equation though. No reason to think the USA would employ them against a non-nuclear power (despite Aug 1945). The immense disparity in conventional capability is significant though

WAR almost always a bad option for one or both belligerents. So why do leaders choose it? Because they overestimate their chances, underestimate the enemy, and cannot afford to appear weak at home. For a leader only thing worse than war is weakness. Which is always why wars start
USA-USSR Cold War showed that escalation could be carefully controlled. But there are plenty of counter-examples that show escalations spiralling out of control as a result of miscalculation

U.S.-Iraq (2003), U.S.-Iraq (1991), Iraq-Iran (1980-88), Falklands (1982), Second World War, First World War etc all resulted from miscalculations about escalation strategy and resolve/capabilities by at least one belligerent

ESCALATION ladders become immensely unstable if BOTH sides try to pursue a dominance strategy and if one or both miscalculate the resolve or resources of the other. It‚Äôs how wars almost always start ....

@razhael @jc_stubbs Best advice to spy agencies is same as for any other organisation: how would this behaviour/policy look on the front page of a newspaper or in front of a hostile congressional committee? If you wouldn't be comfortable defending it, don't do it. Nothing remains secret forever.

@razhael @jc_stubbs Secrecy is necessary in espionage organisations, but it can also permit/encourage deviant behaviour that would be quickly suppressed in more open organisations. OTHER COUNTRIES are too small to care about individually, though they can make a difference in broad aggregates (OECD, non-OECD, emerging markets, Asia, Latin America, Middle East) usually as a result of common global influences (oil prices, global economic cycle etc)

OIL CONSUMING COUNTRIES I care most about:
1st order: China and India (large and fast-growing consumers)
2nd order: United States (large but slow growth)
3rd order: Saudi Arabia, Brazil and maybe Russia (medium, growing fast)
4th order: Germany and Japan (medium, shrinking)

@anasalhajji IR and VE market share has collapsed as a result of U.S. sanctions, so Saudi Arabia's share of OPEC output has been rising. But if we look at whole market (OPEC and non-OPEC) Saudi market share is on long-term downtrend. The big winner from output restraint has been U.S. shale ..

SAUDI ARABIA's oil ministers have usually learned the hard way and ended their careers realising the futility of the market control strategy. Yamani, Naimi and even Falih eventually accepted the limits of the kingdom's power over oil prices. Now Abdulazziz's turn?

SAUDI ARABIA's periods of output restraint are simply creating space for more oil production from rival producers. The kingdom is never able to reclaim lost market share and it gets no lasting rise in prices. The strategy is not working.

SAUDI ARABIA is sacrificing long-term oil market share without any corresponding long-term lift in prices. Output restraint is simply creating more room for U.S. shale and other non-OPEC non-shale producers to grow

@h_ojha Basically, the UK is really two separate economies - one based on London and surrounding areas, the other the rest. They have radically different levels of productivity and living standards. Even massive fiscal transfers from former to  latter are not enough to close the gap

@CMacIver11 The challenge is to improve productivity and wealth creation in the other nine NUTS regions to narrow the gap rather than trying to engineer even more inter-regional transfers. That takes sensible and carefully thought out policies rather than election slogans ...

Raising more taxes/cutting spending in London/SE/East and spending more money in other nine regions is unlikely to make much difference to regional economic performance and disparities. The problems in other nine regions are structural. More govt spending is unlikely to help much

In effect, the super-regional economy centred on London is already cross-subsidising the rest of the country by several thousand pounds per person per year. It's far from clear Britain's problem is insufficient government spending and inter-regional transfers

Of the 12 major geographic regions of the United Kingdom (NUTS 1 areas) just three pay more in tax than they receive in public spending: London, the South East, and East of England. The remaining nine regions all receive more public spending than they pay in tax.

@The_AndyJohnson UK/NATO have never planned to fight a conventional conflict with USSR/Russia so an odd benchmark to use. This story reads like a plea for more spending on troops and equipment, which would be easy if we weren't spending so much on aircraft carriers and expensive nuclear upgrades

@The_AndyJohnson NATO always relied on the threat of using nuclear weapons to deter an attack by what it believed were overwhelmingly larger Soviet/Warsaw Pact conventional forces. It was core NATO strategy. The fact NATO probably over-estimated Soviet numbers and capabilities is another story

BRITAIN's politicians would be wrong to undo rail closures: https://t.co/FbI0in38iu https://t.co/qbpts1UPk0
BUT my middle-class walking holiday by train in Scotland is subsidised by a working-class person who takes a bus in south London ...
I LOVE travelling to the Highlands of Scotland along the improbable west coast line pushed through the mountains from Glasgow to Oban, Fort William and Mallaig. But that route was never economic
THE DIFFERENCE between being a 10-year old kid and a 44-year old "grown up" is that the romance is tempered by reality.

THE STATIONS and lines closed by Beeching's Axe caused local hardship. But it was and is cheaper to provide those services by road (including by bus). Railways with their high fixed capital costs work best for dense traffic routes.

I LOVE travelling by train. When I was a kid, I watched the television dramatisation of John Masefield's "Box of Delights" and fell in love with the romance of the old steam trains and the rural stations. But the reality was they had few passengers and not much freight https://t.co/e1sRLCy5Iz
BY REDUCING or eliminating thousands of barely used local stopping services, Beeching's reorganisation opened up more capacity on the rail network and made fast long-distance express trains possible.

IF YOU enjoy jumping on an express train from London to Manchester, Newcastle or Edinburgh, or you think that trains are a great way to carry cars, aggregates and other freight loads around the country, you can thank Dr Beeching.

BRITAIN's rail network was heavily loss-making before the reorganisation stemming from the Beeching report. Thousands of stations were little used by either passengers or freight and were massively subsidised by the few parts of the system that actually broke even: https://t.co/ESxrkMsGqf
ONE-THIRD of the stations on the network contributed just 1% of the passenger receipts in total. HALF the stations on the network contributed just 2% of passenger receipts https://t.co/3Nw9kNi3nM

ONE-THIRD of the rail network miles carried only 1% of the passenger traffic. The same figures were true for freight traffic. Half the route mileage carried just 7.5% of total passenger and freight traffic (see Beeching's chart below): https://t.co/VxWuWoHupU

[RANT] NO POLITICIAN or journalist should talk about Beeching's axe unless they have read his report on "The Reshaping of British Railways" published in 1963 and still available. The report is short (150 pages) and written in clear non-technical language: https://t.co/ZUwMbIV9P5 https://t.co/ySegv7MCPJ

@Not_MSM_News Most of the tensions in the US/UK relationship predate the current president, though he has arguably sharpened them, and they will remain after he has left the White House in 2021 or 2025. The issues are structural and not about personalities (correcting previous dates!)
@Not_MSM_News I am NOT bashing Trump. I am trying to analyse and discuss Britain's overseas relationships calmly and dispassionately with as much detached rigour as possible. It's what I do :)
@Not_MSM_News British governments have always remained studiously neutral in public about U.S. presidential elections

SO FAR the political, media and social focus has been on UK-EU relations and there has been little discussion of UK-US relations (that defence and security establishment taboo) but changing one relationship profoundly is likely to have major effects on the other

BRITAIN's problem of diminishing power and influence and its complicated and competing relations with the United States and Europe have been a central theme of politics for the last 75 years but the tensions are set to become much sharper in the next decade

Leave/Atlanticist and Remain/Europeanist are arguably emerging as distinct political and social identities within the United Kingdom which could generate significant challenges for managing both U.K. alliances in future

BREXIT and the Atlantic Alliance are becoming deeply entwined with each other. Brexiteers and ardent Atlanticists show very substantial overlap. And the much discussed "freedom to do our own trade deals" seems mostly to be about freedom to do our own deal with the United States

BREXIT is both a cause and a consequence of re-opening questions about the United Kingdom's place in the world. Brexit has already re-opened questions about relations with the EU and the Union between kingdoms. It will probably also re-open questions about the Atlantic Alliance

@PrometheusAM I'm simply noting that the degree of partisan support in an internal election is unusual ... If Labour were led by another individual, would Trump be any less strongly supportive of Johnson?

OLDER GENERATIONS still have a strong Atlanticist outlook stemming from WW2 and the Cold War. But those references are less important for younger generations. Public support for the Alliance likely shows the same generational divide as Brexit (and the two overlap substantially)
BRITAIN's extremely close alliance with the United States is arguably distorting its foreign policy and relations with other states, and may or may not be in the interest of the United Kingdom

But as the United States pivots to Asia and great power competition with China and a rapprochement with Russia, and Britain's relative military and economic power continues to diminish, the costs and benefits of the alliance need to be thought through in London

U.K. DEFENCE, security and intelligence agencies are so deeply entwined with the United States that even talking about the costs and benefits of the alliance for the United Kingdom has become taboo in foreign policy circles here

KEY QUESTION for the United Kingdom over the next 10-20 years is whether the benefits of the U.S. alliance outweigh the costs, or whether Britain should seek a different relationship. The answer is not obvious.

U.S./U.K. RELATIONSHIP has never been fully reciprocal since 1945 (and arguably not since 1918 as Britain declined as a global power). But it is becoming increasingly lopsided and now almost totally unilateral.
NO EVIDENCE that the United Kingdom plays any significant role in shaping U.S./Alliance strategy or U.K. interests are given any special priority by top U.S. policymakers.

TRUMP's repeated interventions in British politics are reminiscent of Rome's interference in its client kingdoms, or Athen's domination of the Delian League. The Western Alliance has become an American Empire in which "allies" are really client states: https://t.co/PT3OkT8sdX

TRAVEL TIMES were cut significantly as a result of the road revolution. For example, the total time for a journey by passenger coach between London and Manchester decreased from around 90 hours in 1700 to 60 hours in 1760, 24 hours in 1787 and 19 hours in 1821

ENGLAND‚Äôs transport revolution in the 18th century.
